short_label: Reporting rising rates and worsening statistics
long_description: This feature activates on expository passages that describe increasing prevalence, severity, or spread of problems using quantitative or comparative statistics (e.g., higher rates, more cases, worsening conditions over time). The text typically highlights trends like doubling, record highs, or dramatic increases in disease, environmental damage, or social issues, often framed as especially severe or unprecedented.
rationale: Many snippets emphasize growth or worsening over time with numerical or superlative framing: “by far the worst such event since the phenomenon was first identified” and “levels…approaching zero” for oxygen loss [0]; “extremly high levels…almost five times the treshold” and worst health effects in India [1]; “high numbers reflect a true increase” in COVID-19 infections with rising hospitalizations and deaths [2]; drought area “more than doubled” and severe drought up “more than 400 percent” [3]; obesity rates where many states now exceed thresholds that none did previously [8]; methane and manure quantities contributing to warming with each year “getting hotter” [9]; tick infection rates “higher than expected” [10]; and infection “exacerbated…earlier onset, accelerated progression, and enhanced severity” in a disease model [11]. These all share the semantic pattern of describing escalating negative metrics or trends, not a specific moral foundation.

short_label: Word-game anagram and Scrabble list formatting
long_description: This feature activates on structured word-game content, especially pages listing anagrams and Scrabble words derivable from a given word, often with headings for word lengths and boilerplate about Scrabble trademarks or wildcard letters. It also appears with similar list-like, rule-based educational or assessment formats such as rubrics and stepwise math explanations.
rationale: Many snippets are from Scrabble/anagram helper pages that repeat a fixed template: “All anagrams that could be made from letters of word X plus a … Scrabble words that can be created with letters from word X … 10 letter words … 2 letter words … SCRABBLE is the registered trademark … we merely provide help” [4][5][6][9][10]. These share a strong structural and topical pattern around word games and letter permutations. Related evidence includes other highly structured educational or evaluative formats, like an essay rubric with trait scales [7] and a stepwise system-of-equations/least-squares explanation [8], which match the same procedural, list-oriented style. The remaining snippets do not suggest a coherent moral or authority-related theme, so no MFT category is appropriate.

short_label: Planning and designing structured programs or courses
long_description: This feature activates for texts that describe planning, designing, or structuring formal programs or courses—such as training, educational curricula, transitional programs, or policy frameworks—often outlining steps, stakeholders, goals, and methods. The emphasis is on organized, systematic approaches to achieving objectives in institutional or organizational contexts.
rationale: Many snippets discuss creating or improving structured programs within institutions, implying respect for organized processes and expert or institutional guidance. Examples include defining projects to meet organizational goals [0], establishing governmental authority and frameworks for crisis management [1], outlining stages of the writing process for classroom teaching [2], collaborative decision-making for school ICT integration [3], building transitional programs for students with disabilities with guidance for parents, teachers, and administrators [4], planning soft skills training [5], designing engagement/education programs for patients [6], focusing on foundational aspects of poverty alleviation programs [7], assessing training needs before conducting training programs in organizations [8], optimizing antibiotic use through policy and practical planning [9], and instructional strategies in character education courses [10]. These all reflect deference to structured, often institutional planning and expertise, aligning with the Authority foundation in its virtue form (valuing organized guidance and legitimate structures).

short_label: Epidemiological risk rates and health statistics
long_description: This feature activates on quantitative epidemiological reporting, especially percentages, incidence or mortality rates, and comparative risk statistics in public health or medical contexts. The snippets typically describe population-level health outcomes, case-fatality rates, or behavior-related health risks using formal statistical language.
rationale: Many snippets present health-related statistics such as increased risk of death, case-fatality rates, incidence estimates, and comparative outcome percentages in clinical trials or population studies [0][1][2][3][4][8][9][10][11]. Others similarly discuss quantified health or hygiene risks (infection spread, diet-related disease, bone loss) in a scientific or public health framing [5][7][9][10]. The common pattern is not moral evaluation but formal, numerical description of health risks and outcomes at the population level, so no specific Moral Foundations category applies.

short_label: Section headings and bullet-pointed list structure
long_description: This feature activates on texts organized into explicit sections, headings, or bullet-pointed lists that enumerate attributes, chapters, or data fields in a structured way. It is sensitive to catalog-style formatting such as titled sections followed by dash- or bullet-led items describing properties or contents.
rationale: Many snippets show clear section or chapter titles followed by organized subitems or bullet points. Example [0] lists title-page components and chapter headings; [1] is a structured attribute list for plants with repeated dash-prefixed fields; [2] begins with a software title and release info in a structured header; [5] and [8] have labeled sections like “Our Brewery and Process” or “Location:” followed by descriptive fields; [6] lists labeled Olympic host data; [10] and [11] are scientific/medical abstracts with clearly demarcated aims or symptom/treatment descriptions. The commonality is document-style structural metadata and enumerated properties, not any moral content.

short_label: Q&A advice column answer responses
long_description: This feature activates on answer segments in advice or Q&A columns, where an expert responds directly to a reader’s question, often beginning with an address or explanation and providing guidance or clarification. The style is explanatory, authoritative, and supportive, frequently following a quoted question with an “A:” section that elaborates on causes, context, and recommended actions.
rationale: Many snippets are clearly from advice or expert Q&A formats, with an 'A:' introducing an authoritative response to a prior question. The responder adopts an expert, guiding tone: explaining research or diagnostic criteria [1], advising a parent on educational focus for a gifted child [2], diagnosing plant or lawn problems and suggesting what to do [3],[7], giving medical/vaccine explanations and recommendations [4], interpreting child cheating behavior developmentally and advising on parenting [5], clarifying evolving language norms around marriage [6], explaining usage history of phrases [8], confirming and elaborating on carbohydrate counting guidelines [9], distinguishing obedience from sociability and advising on dog behavior [10], and validating a mother’s concern while referencing clinical experience [11]. The common pattern is an authoritative, explanatory answer to a layperson’s question, which aligns with the Authority foundation in its virtuous form (respect for expertise and guidance).

short_label: Citations, credentials, and institutional attributions
long_description: This feature activates on text that attributes information to authoritative sources, including named experts with credentials, formal organizations, historical institutions, and cited publications or exhibitions. It often appears in bylines, reference lists, institutional descriptions, and explanatory notes that establish provenance or authority for the surrounding content.
rationale: Many snippets explicitly foreground institutional or expert authority: a named medical doctor with board certification and training is presented as the source of information [0]; formal organizational references and URLs are listed as sources (American Heart Association, FDA) in a citation-style format [1]; an imperial abbey is described with its official status and historical titles within the Holy Roman Empire [2]; a press release is attributed to GAVI and quotes the UN Secretary-General, emphasizing institutional backing [3]; curriculum guidance is framed as coming from an official national curriculum and treaty principles [4]; a quotation is contextualized with the historical identity and moral stance (abolitionist) of a notable figure [5]; scientific research is attributed to a specific journal issue and a national study [6]; a scientific field’s history is narrated around a group of scientists at an annual meeting [7]; a language-learning site explains the formal second-person pronoun usage, invoking grammatical authority [8]; an art exhibition is described in terms of Renaissance artists’ engagement with the classical heritage and a curated institutional display [11]. These all share the rhetorical function of grounding statements in recognized authorities or institutions, aligning with the Authority foundation as a virtue (respecting and invoking legitimate expertise and institutions).

short_label: Formal informational / reference-style exposition
long_description: This feature activates on formal, expository text that presents factual or instructional information in a structured, reference-like style, often including classifications, statuses, measurements, or academic/course details. The snippets typically describe entities or systems in a neutral, technical tone (e.g., species diagnoses, endangered status listings, course requirements, physical dimensions, or scientific explanations).
rationale: Many snippets are neutral, technical descriptions: academic course descriptions and requirements [0][4], formal rulebook language for sports officiating [1], taxonomic diagnosis of a species [2], conservation status listings with standardized ranks [3], technical/academic discussion of systems thinking and economics [5], a reference-style description of a greenhouse from a gardening manual [6], a mission description for a lunar spacecraft and relay satellite [7], a museum-style description of a Viking warship [9], a tabular physical description of a reservoir [10], and a technical astrophysical explanation of resonances and orbits [11]. Even [8], which is more value-laden, is formatted as a formal school program description. The common thread is expository, informational prose rather than any specific moral content, so no Moral Foundations category is clearly implicated.

short_label: Formal expository and academic-style writing
long_description: This feature activates on formal, expository prose such as research abstracts, instructional or reference text, structured essays, and survey-based business analysis. The snippets share an informative, academic or semi-academic tone with organized presentation of facts, definitions, or arguments rather than narrative or casual conversation.
rationale: Most snippets are written in a formal, informational style: a scientific study abstract about soil and metals [0], a structured plant reference entry [1], a technical man-page–like description of a Linux command [3], an assignment/contest prompt for a formal essay on freedom [4], instructions and thesis discussion for writing about Shakespearean sonnets [5], a table-of-contents style breakdown of a historical/geographical text [6], a public-health expository piece on tobacco use in Guam [7], a philosophical-popular science exposition on life extension [8], an art-criticism style museum description [9], a business/finance explanation of mergers and acquisitions with survey data [10], and a travel-themed but still essayistic, descriptive magazine-style piece [11]. These are unified by expository, structured, relatively formal prose rather than any clear moral-foundation content.

short_label: Introductory background and definitional openings
long_description: This feature activates on passages that introduce a topic or entity with concise background information, often defining what it is, its role, or its historical/biographical context before elaborating further. The snippets commonly start sections or articles by situating the reader with basic facts, dates, or explanations of a concept or person.
rationale: Several snippets clearly function as introductory background: defining inflammation and why it occurs [1], giving basic production and usage facts about Zea mays [2], introducing a state mapping task force and its process [3], opening a theological discussion by situating a biblical passage and its author [6], and providing a brief biographical introduction to Eusebius of Laodicea with role and dates [7]. Others similarly open with contextual framing, such as the BMJ review of COVID-19 antibody tests [5], the setup of a personal narrative about a mother in Burundi [8], the introduction of Greta Thunberg and her influence on the art world [9], and the description of a child’s history of Scotland book and its scope [10]. These all share the rhetorical function of orienting the reader with core identifying information at the start of a section or article, rather than expressing a specific moral stance.

short_label: Introductory definitional or contextual statements
long_description: This feature activates on sentences that introduce or define a topic, person, place, or process in an expository way, often serving as the opening contextual statement of a paragraph or article. These snippets typically state what something is, its role or importance, or that a particular treatment, series, or process exists, before elaborating further.
rationale: Many snippets are clear introductory or definitional sentences: defining an art movement and its significance [2], introducing a national anthem and basic country facts [4], opening a human-interest story with generational context [5], marking the transition to the data analysis phase [6], explaining what lye originally referred to and how it is used [7], introducing a new treatment and its publication context [8], defining vitamin B complex and its components [9], describing a training series and its purpose [10], and broadly introducing light therapy and its general benefits [11]. These all function as initial, high-level context-setting statements rather than detailed explanations or arguments. The taxonomic and biographical snippets [0],[1] also begin with naming and basic identifying information, consistent with this pattern. There is no consistent moral or evaluative content, so no Moral Foundations category is appropriate.

short_label: Section titles, headings, and labeled list items
long_description: This feature activates on structured document elements such as section or chapter titles, labeled list items, and short heading-like phrases that introduce or categorize content (e.g., “Title Pages,” “Tree or Plant Type,” “Host City,” “Date Started”). It reflects the rhetorical function of organizing or labeling information rather than narrative prose.
rationale: Many snippets begin with or prominently feature short, capitalized or colon-terminated labels that function as headings or field names: “Title Pages – Editor's Introduction – A Note on the Text…” [0], “All Common Names: Tree or Plant Type: – Deciduous…” [1], “Host City: London, Great Britain / Date Started: July 29, 1948 / Date Finished: August 14, 1948 / Participants: …” [5], and “Our Brewery and Process How Ohio Craft Beer Is Made / See Our Beers / Process, Descriptions and Ingredients in our beers” [10]. Even in more narrative contexts, there are clear titled sections like “Mutidetector Computed Tomography and its Uses In Radiological Imaging” [9] and “The Garden Museum explores the woodland paintings of Ivon Hitchens” [11]. These patterns indicate the feature is tied to structural headings and labeled list fields, not to moral content.

short_label: Numbered sections, lists, and question items
long_description: This feature activates on structured, numbered formatting such as section headings, list items, question numbering, and labeled subsections (e.g., 2.1.4, 3 X 4 points, numbered examples). It reflects recognition of formal document or exercise structure rather than any particular topic or moral stance.
rationale: Many snippets show hierarchical section numbering and list notation: academic or report-style subsections like “2.1.4”, “2.2.1”, “2.4.1” etc. [0], point allocations and numbered questions like “X 9 points), 3 questions from Brian (3 X 4 points)” [1], and numbered equations or sequences such as “an = 4n – 3…….1” and “a17 and a24” [9]. There are also repeated date and volume/issue formats that follow similar numeric-structural patterns [3][8][11]. These all indicate the feature is keyed to the presence of explicit numbering and structured list/section formats, not to moral content.

short_label: Definition or explanation of a term/topic
long_description: This feature activates on passages that introduce and define a term, place, condition, or concept, often beginning with a phrase like “The term X refers to…”, “Castile…”, or “Pleural thickening is…”, and then providing explanatory background or classification. The style is expository and encyclopedic, focused on clarifying what something is and sometimes its historical or technical context.
rationale: Several snippets clearly start by naming a subject and then explaining or defining it: “Castile(redirected from Castilla)… historic region and former kingdom” [3], “The term day care or child care refers to the care of a child…” [6], “Pleural thickening is a condition of the lungs that is most often caused by…” [8], and “According to an urban legend, dust is made up of human skin. Of course in reality… So what exactly is dust comprised of…” [10]. Others similarly introduce and describe a topic in an informational tone, such as the Amur tiger’s status [4], Baloch love for homeland in a cultural-historical frame [5], the history of a city block and its foundry [7], and an overview of U.S. history and the flag’s evolution [11]. These are all neutral, explanatory uses rather than moral evaluations, so no specific moral foundation applies.

short_label: Explanatory or definitional introductory sentences
long_description: This feature activates on opening sentences or brief passages that introduce and define a topic, event, place, or concept in an expository, reference-style manner. The text typically presents what something is, its purpose, or contextual basics before further detail, as in encyclopedia entries, legal definitions, or informational guides.
rationale: Many snippets are clearly the first, framing sentence of an expository piece that defines or introduces a subject: a philosophical question about living forever [0], an annual student essay event and its sponsor [1], a bridge and its location and significance [2], a disease and a song about its spread and control [3], a yachting crew and their scientific mission [4], a historic district and its boundaries [5], a legal term and its purpose in court [6], an article about foods to avoid for glucose balance [7], a Linux command implementation and its basis [8], a kids’ book and its subject matter [9], a sport and its origin and rules [10], and a medical discovery and Nobel recognition [11]. The commonality is not moral content but the rhetorical function of concise, definitional introductions.

short_label: Assessing or rating condition or quality
long_description: This feature activates on language that evaluates the condition, quality, or state of something (health, environment, objects, systems) using explicit ratings or qualitative labels such as excellent, good, poor, desirable, or in relatively poor condition. It often appears in technical, scientific, or official assessments that classify status or performance levels.
rationale: Multiple snippets explicitly describe graded conditions or states: health or physical condition rated on a scale with terms like excellent and poor [1], ecological or environmental systems rated as in relatively poor condition or given comparative ratings [2],[5], objects described as in good to fair condition [3], and system states evaluated as desirable or undesirable [9]. These all share the semantic pattern of assessing and labeling the condition or quality of something, often in a formal or technical context. While some contexts involve health or environment, the core pattern is evaluative classification, not a specific moral foundation.

short_label: Definitions and hierarchies of roles and positions
long_description: This feature activates on text that defines, explains, or contrasts formal roles, titles, and positions within organizations or structured systems, often including their place in a hierarchy and associated responsibilities or competencies. It spans corporate, academic, governmental, technical, and online community contexts where roles are categorized, ranked, or distinguished from one another.
rationale: Many snippets explicitly describe formal positions and their rank within a structured hierarchy (executive vs team members, associate professor between ranks, city council titles, engineering grades) or delineate role-based authority and responsibilities (admins with special powers, housekeeper in charge of staff, Six Sigma belt levels, technician competency levels). These are classic expressions of social and organizational authority structures and role differentiation, aligning with the Authority foundation in its descriptive, order-maintaining sense rather than subversion or disrespect. Evidence includes hierarchical leadership and team roles [0], academic rank between assistant and full professor [1], distinction between clerical and executive positions [2], graded competency levels for technicians [3], Six Sigma belt hierarchy and roles [4], elected council roles and titles [5], responsibility over cleaning staff [6], generic vs skilled roles in a play and work context [7], advisory councils/boards and NEDs as governance roles [8], admins with special powers over a site [9], salary bands by grade for engineers [10], and business/management positions and HR manager role [11].

short_label: Definitions and formal explanatory statements
long_description: This feature activates on text that provides formal definitions or structured explanatory statements about concepts, metrics, or facts, often in an educational or reference style. The snippets include explicit definitional phrasing and systematic explanation of terms or principles, such as probability, medical screening recommendations, and technical measures like Total Acid Number.
rationale: Several snippets clearly define or explain concepts in a formal, didactic way. Snippet [4] explicitly begins with “Probability is a branch of mathematics that deals with…”, a textbook-style definition. Snippet [5] is a labeled definition of TAN, including what it stands for and how it is measured. Snippet [1] systematically lists recommended screening tests with structured criteria, reflecting formal guideline-style exposition. Snippet [0] explains resilience theory and stable states in a structured, conceptual way. Snippet [3] explains expected gain in motor strategies using formal probabilistic language. These all point to a feature keyed to definitional or formal explanatory content rather than any moral theme.

short_label: Section headings and labeled list structures
long_description: This feature activates on texts organized into explicit sections or bullet-style entries, where each line begins with a label or heading followed by a brief description or data point. It commonly appears in tables of contents, structured lists of attributes, event summaries, or process descriptions that use consistent heading–detail formatting.
rationale: Many snippets are dominated by line-initial labels followed by short explanatory fragments, indicating a structural rather than semantic theme. Example patterns include a table-of-contents style list of chapters and front matter [0], a catalog of plant attributes with label–value pairs [1], a structured software description with name, date, copyright, and explanation [3], an Olympic-style event summary with labeled fields like Host City, Date Started, Participants [4], a school essay contest description with name, grade, and sponsor information [9], and a brewery process page with repeated section headings such as “See Our Beers” and process descriptions [10]. These show the feature is keyed to formatted headings and enumerated or bullet-like informational lines rather than any particular moral content.

short_label: Quantitative demographic and statistical reporting
long_description: This feature activates on expository text that reports quantitative statistics about populations, health metrics, or institutional structures, often with percentages, ranges, and measurement units. The style is neutral and data-focused, summarizing demographic distributions, medical norms, economic figures, or course descriptions using precise numerical details.
rationale: Many snippets present demographic or population statistics with percentages and counts, such as household composition and age distribution [0], English language learner percentages [6], Singapore’s resident vs nonresident population numbers [8], and agricultural price supports and export markets [7]. Others report quantitative biomedical or physiological ranges and study outcomes, including normal potassium levels with specific mEq/L ranges [1], blood pressure changes with confidence intervals and p-values [2], and pregnancy-related slide-positive frequencies with means and standard deviations [11]. Additional evidence includes quantified exercise calorie expenditures [9], vehicle dimensions and weights [5], and catalog-style course descriptions with credit hours [10]. Across these, the common pattern is neutral, factual reporting of numerical data rather than any moral or authority-related content, so no Moral Foundations category clearly applies.

short_label: Defining standards, objectives, and requirements
long_description: This feature activates on explanatory text that defines or describes formal standards, objectives, requirements, or rules for quality, safety, or performance in institutional or technical contexts. It often appears in instructional or guideline-style prose outlining what standards are, why objectives matter, and how they should be structured or applied.
rationale: Many snippets explicitly define or explain standards and their role (e.g., care standards, early years service standards, consumer product safety standards) [0,1,3,8]. Others describe objectives and outcomes in structured, procedural contexts such as internships, food safety, test cases, and instructional design [4,5,6,10]. Additional snippets discuss requirements and rules for business documents and software behavior, reinforcing the theme of formalized requirements and compliance-oriented guidelines [2,11]. Together these indicate a semantic pattern around articulating and structuring standards, objectives, and requirements rather than a moral foundation per se.

short_label: Expository informational and instructional writing
long_description: This feature activates on neutral, expository prose that explains concepts, processes, or background information, often in educational, scientific, religious, or how‑to contexts. The snippets share a didactic tone, defining terms, giving context, or outlining steps rather than narrating events or expressing opinions.
rationale: Across the evidence, the commonality is an informational, instructive style: medical or biological explanations and definitions ([0], [4], [9], [10], [11]), religious or historical exposition ([1], [6]), procedural or how‑to guides ([2], [3], [5]), and an explanatory article about activism’s influence on art ([7]) and a conceptual explanation of a phenomenon ([8]). These are all examples of expository writing aimed at explaining or instructing, not primarily expressing moral judgment, so no specific Moral Foundations category is implicated.

short_label: Advice-column style Q&A with named addressee
long_description: This feature activates on advice-style question-and-answer formats where a reader addresses an expert with a salutation (e.g., “Dear Dr. Dirt,” “Dear Mr. Dad,” “DEAR DOCTOR K”) and receives an explanatory, often didactic response. The pattern centers on this quasi-epistolary Q&A structure rather than any specific topic, covering parenting, gardening, psychology, and medical or practical advice.
rationale: Multiple snippets show a consistent structure: a question from a layperson introduced with a salutation and sometimes a signature, followed by an expert’s labeled answer. Examples include “Dear Dr. Dirt: The leaves are coming down…” with “Dear Reader: First, you need a container…” [1], “Dear Mr. Dad: My six-year-old son has suddenly begun cheating…” with “A: If you hadn’t told me your son’s age…” [2], “DEAR DOCTOR K: I have a terrible fear of heights…” with “DEAR READER: We all have things we worry about…” [5], and similar Q&A advice exchanges in [4], [6], [7], [9], [10], and [11]. The commonality is the advice-column rhetorical format, not a specific moral theme, so mapping to Moral Foundations Theory is not warranted.

short_label: Metric/imperial unit conversions and dimensions
long_description: This feature activates on factual descriptions that pair metric and imperial measurements or convert between numerical units, often in lists or explanatory text about sizes, distances, prices, focal lengths, or spans. The pattern centers on concrete quantitative comparisons such as km vs miles, cm vs inches, currency equivalences, or multiplicative lens factors.
rationale: Multiple snippets explicitly present side‑by‑side metric and imperial units or other unit conversions: km and miles for island size [4], miles and km plus square feet and km² for a factory [7], cm and inches for fruit size [9], inches and cm for butterfly wingspan [10], and cm and inches for a flag patch [11]. Others show numeric conversion relationships, such as exchange rate effects on meal prices [0], historical price equivalences across currencies and commodities [5], and multiplicative focal length changes (200*1.4, 200*1.7, etc.) for camera lenses [8]. These all indicate a semantic focus on quantitative unit relationships rather than any moral content.

short_label: Formal informational or instructional headings and sections
long_description: This feature activates on structured, formal non-fiction text that uses headings, title pages, chapter lists, component lists, or assignment prompts to organize information or instructions (e.g., academic, technical, governmental, or religious documents). It especially tracks section titles and meta-textual labels that frame how the following content should be read or used.
rationale: Many snippets are dominated by explicit headings or structural labels: “Title Pages / Editor's Introduction / Chapter I…” in a table-of-contents style list [4]; “Components of population growth / Information identified as archived…” with government-web meta notices [11]; “All Common Names: / Tree or Plant Type:” followed by bullet-point attributes [2]; “Host City: London, Great Britain / Date Started: July 29, 1948…” listing structured event metadata [10]; and “rlocate for Linux (2.6 Kernel) / Released January 27, 2005 / Copyright…” as a software documentation header [9]. Others show assignment-style or essay-prompt framing like “Write an essay on the shakespeare sonnets / Thesis statement for shakespeares sonnets…” [5] and “all students … were asked to write an essay titled ‘What Freedom Means to Me.’ This annual event, sponsored by…” [8]. Even the religious and public-health texts begin with formal, declarative headings or mission-like statements (e.g., “DID JESUS OBSERVE THE PASSOVER? A.M.D.G.” [1]; “Guam is in the midst of an epidemic of tobacco use.” as a policy-style opener [3]). Across domains, the commonality is not topic or morality but the presence of formal, expository headings and organizational scaffolding. There is no consistent moral valence or specific moral foundation across these varied informational contexts, so mapping to MFT is unwarranted.

short_label: Institutional roles, rules, and protective authority
long_description: This feature activates around descriptions of formal institutions and authorities (governments, charities, churches, schools, media, regulatory bodies) carrying out structured, often protective or supervisory functions, including war declarations, investigations, child protection, educational programs, and official guidance. The text typically explains what these bodies do, their responsibilities, or how to properly interact with or use them.
rationale: Multiple snippets center on formal authorities acting in official capacities: national governments declaring war and exercising sovereign choice (Canada and Britain in WWII) [0], a charity and related mechanisms protecting children from online sexual abuse [6], Congress managing the federal budget and debt ceiling to keep government functioning [8], and students prompting a federal investigation into nuclear reactor security [7]. Others describe institutional or authoritative structures and guidance: bravery awards administered by the Indian state to recognize valorous children [9], a pope/saint’s ecclesiastical and civic roles [4], a structured music program for teachers and parents [3], and instructions on using government or academic websites as reliable sources [11]. These all reflect respect for and description of legitimate authority, institutional roles, and rule-governed procedures, aligning with the Authority foundation in a positive/functional way.

short_label: Organizational process and operations management
long_description: This feature activates on expository descriptions of formal organizational processes and operational functions, such as logistics, supply chain, records, data, inventory, procurement, and accounts receivable management. The text typically defines a domain, outlines its objectives, and explains structured procedures or systems used to control and coordinate organizational activities.
rationale: All snippets describe structured, often departmentalized organizational functions and their processes: inventory management in pharmacies [0], data architecture and governance [1], document and records management [2][7][10], procurement [3], logistics and logistics management [4][5][6], multi-company supply chain synchronization [8], IT governance [9], and accounts receivable/debtors processes [11]. The common pattern is neutral, procedural explanation of how organizations structure, control, and manage operational workflows, not a moral stance about authority or other foundations.

short_label: Awarding points, scores, and bonus credit
long_description: This feature activates on language about assigning or earning points, scores, or extra credit in games, activities, rubrics, or evaluations, often in instructional or descriptive contexts. It includes phrases like “award a point,” “extra points,” “points are awarded,” and “maximum points” tied to performance or correct answers.
rationale: Multiple snippets explicitly describe giving or earning points for performance: awarding points to children who identify animal footprints correctly and the child with the most points winning the game [3]; points awarded for rocket paths that meet certain criteria [7]; an A–Z sheet point scale with specific letter values and total score, plus extra points for more than one answer [9]; and earning maximum points in a judging rubric’s technical section [11]. Other snippets use “extra points” or similar evaluative phrasing in non-game contexts, such as extra points for using certain foods [1], extra points for practical value in selecting milestones [2], and bonus points for stylistic writing feats [0], reinforcing the general pattern of point-based evaluation or reward.

short_label: Numbered instructional or Q&A step formatting
long_description: This feature activates on texts that use explicit numbered or lettered steps, questions, or list items in instructional, explanatory, or Q&A formats (e.g., “Step 1:…”, “1.”, “Q.” followed by guidance or answers). It reflects structured, didactic presentation of information rather than any particular topic or moral stance.
rationale: Multiple snippets show explicit stepwise or question-number formatting: health instructions with “Step 2: Do's and Don'ts” and numbered lists [6], Arduino setup with “Step 1: Materials… Step 2: Setting Up…” and bullet/step structure [8], math guidance with sequentially numbered questions “43 Q. Which total did you use next?… 44 Q. Which total did you use last?… 45 Last you should have worked out that…” [9]. Other snippets also contain list-like or itemized structures (e.g., enumerated points about Bitcoin mining [3], vocabulary examples with bullet-like markers [7]), supporting that the core pattern is structured, enumerated instructional or Q&A text rather than content-specific semantics or moral themes.

short_label: Citation-style references and attributions
long_description: This feature activates on formal citation or attribution lines, especially naming organizations, authors, credentials, dates, and access notes in a reference-like format. It often appears in bibliographic entries, author bylines, or quoted attributions within academic or informational text.
rationale: Snippet [0] shows a formal reference with organization name, article title, URL, and access date, which is classic citation formatting. Snippet [5] includes an attributed quotation with dates for Oscar Wilde, again in a reference/attribution style. Snippet [10] is an author byline listing full name, degree, board certification, and educational background, which is another structured attribution. These all point to a feature keyed to bibliographic or authorial reference structures rather than moral content.

short_label: Expository definitional and introductory sentences
long_description: This feature activates on neutral, expository prose that introduces a topic with concise definitions, overviews, or opening guidance, often at the start of an article or section. The snippets typically explain what something is, outline its purpose, or set context in an informational, textbook- or guide-like style.

short_label: Expository informational and reference-style writing
long_description: This feature activates on neutral, expository prose that presents factual or instructional information, often in an encyclopedic, textbook, or reference-entry style, including definitions, tables of properties, how-to guidance, and descriptive overviews. The snippets focus on conveying knowledge clearly rather than argument or narrative, covering topics like etymology, pharmacology, health advice, natural history, and study prompts.
rationale: Many snippets are structured as informational or reference material: etymological explanation and dictionary-style tracing of word origins [0]; a pharmacological data table listing bioavailability, metabolism, half-life, and excretion [1]; a health explainer about flu season risks and media coverage [3]; a vocabulary mini-glossary defining outspoken/plain-spoken/unspoken [4]; practical dental health advice in a how-to format [6]; a descriptive guide to features of a wood, like ancient beeches and their history [7]; a reference-style religious/encyclopedic citation about the pronunciation of Yahweh’s name with sources listed [8]; a research summary from NIH explaining findings on colon and rectal cancers [9]; a species-style entry for Red Elm with common/scientific names, distribution, and size [10]; and an essay prompt that analytically frames a topic and sub-questions [11]. These share a didactic, expository function rather than a moral or evaluative one, so no specific Moral Foundations category is implicated.

short_label: Explanatory or introductory informational passages
long_description: This feature activates on expository, informational text that introduces a topic or figure and then explains background, context, or instructions in a neutral, didactic tone. The snippets often begin with a definitional or scene‑setting sentence and proceed to elaborate with factual details or guidance rather than argument or narrative drama.
rationale: Many snippets are clearly expository introductions: a Bible study lesson setting up a passage and its context [0], a travelogue opening that situates the reader in San Juan and describes the old wall [1], an article introducing Greta Thunberg and her influence on the art world with factual framing [2], a historical overview of Malaya from 1945–1957 [3], a medical review summary about weaknesses in COVID-19 antibody test evidence [6], an encyclopedic-style description of Zea mays and its global production and uses [7], step-by-step craft/activity instructions [8], a brief biographical entry on Eusebius of Laodicea [9], an introductory guide to tree pruning [10], and an explainer on antibiotic use in meat farming and its effects [11]. These share a neutral, explanatory style rather than a moral or evaluative focus, so no specific Moral Foundations category is implicated.

short_label: Technical networking and infrastructure explanations
long_description: This feature activates on expository technical text explaining computer networking, infrastructure, and related IT systems (e.g., VLANs, firewalls, RAID, IPv6, Kubernetes, storage types), often in a tutorial or Q&A style. The snippets focus on defining concepts, describing how technologies work, and outlining configuration or migration considerations in networked or distributed environments.
rationale: All snippets are neutral technical documentation or Q&A about infrastructure and networking topics: VLANs and switches [0], ephemeral instance storage [1], Kubernetes operators and controllers [2], secure protected networks [3], WCF duplex contracts [4], XPath usage in Selenium [5], database table migration and integrity constraints [6], water holing and social engineering attacks in a security context [7], firewall and proxy access control [8], Ethernet bonding and redundancy [9], IPv6 temporary addresses and privacy extensions [10], and RAID levels and IP subnetting [11]. The common pattern is detailed explanation of networking/infrastructure mechanisms and configurations, not moral evaluation or social behavior, so no Moral Foundations category applies.

short_label: Section titles, headings, and list-like outlines
long_description: This feature activates on text that consists largely of section titles, headings, or bullet-point style outline elements, often in an informational or academic context (e.g., chapter lists, labeled attributes, or component lists). It reflects structural, meta-textual organization of documents rather than narrative content itself.
rationale: Several snippets are dominated by headings or enumerated sections: a table of contents with chapter titles [0], a structured list of plant attributes with label–value bullets [1], and a labeled list-style explanation of population growth components with archival notice and meta-formatting language [11]. Other snippets include explicit essay prompts or titled questions (e.g., “Write an essay on…”, “DID JESUS OBSERVE THE PASSOVER?”, “Components of population growth”) that function as headings or section openers [2][7][8][9][11]. The common pattern is document-structuring titles and outline-like lists, not any particular moral theme.

short_label: Explanatory or informational article introductions
long_description: This feature activates on introductory paragraphs or blurbs that summarize what an article, guide, or entry will cover, often defining a topic, posing a question, or previewing key points in an informational tone. The snippets typically open with context-setting statements and then outline what the reader will learn or what the piece discusses, across diverse subjects like history, health, agriculture, and how‑to guides.
rationale: Many snippets are clearly the opening or overview of an article or reference entry, giving a concise description of the subject and its significance. Examples include short descriptions of a book or historical topic [1,4], how‑to or instructional guides [2,8], health and medical explainers [5,6,9,11], and topical issue summaries like climate activism [10] or food insecurity in a family profile [3]. They share a common rhetorical function: orienting the reader to the topic and purpose of the text in an expository, informational style, rather than expressing moral judgment or argumentation, so no specific Moral Foundations category is implicated.

short_label: Expository definitions and purpose statements
long_description: This feature activates on expository or instructional text that defines a concept or term and explains its purpose or function, often in formal or educational contexts. It frequently appears in dictionary-style definitions, study aims, assignment prompts, and explanations of what something is supposed to do or mean.
rationale: Several snippets are explicit definitional passages: a legal term is defined in formal style (“Definition of Summary Judgment… A summary judgment is a decision made by the court…,” [9]); a software tool is introduced with what it is and does (“rlocate is an implementation of the `locate` command that is always up-to-date,” [1]); a scientific paper states its aim and describes measured properties ([6]); a plant information sheet lists categorical properties ([2]); and an educational unit outline lists standards and lesson topics ([10]). Others are assignment-style prompts or meta-descriptions of what something is or is for, such as the essay assignment on freedom ([5]) and on Shakespeare’s sonnets ([8]), and the child’s comment about what art is “supposed to be for” ([3]). The Nobel Prize example also explains what a drug was used for and how it proved efficacy ([7]). These all share a neutral, expository function of defining, categorizing, or stating the purpose of something, without a clear moral-foundation focus.

short_label: Definitions and explanatory reference-style sentences
long_description: This feature activates on concise, reference-style explanations that define terms, clarify concepts, or provide factual background, often in dictionary or encyclopedia tone (e.g., defining ‘hypothetical imperative’ vs ‘categorical imperative,’ explaining program statistics, or giving etymologies and taxonomic notes). The common pattern is neutral, expository prose focused on giving a clear definition or informative description rather than narrative or opinion.
rationale: Snippet [2] explicitly presents dictionary-style definitions of philosophical terms, including contrastive explanation. Snippet [1] describes what a specific book is and its purpose in a neutral, informative way. Snippet [3] explains participation statistics in a federal food program with factual context. Snippet [6] and [10] provide etymological and taxonomic explanations (Greek roots, scientific naming, order Odonata). Snippet [11] introduces a list of grain alternatives with a brief explanatory preface. These all share a definitional or explanatory reference tone rather than a moral stance, even when the content touches on rights or social programs.

short_label: Explanatory definitions and clarifying descriptions
long_description: This feature activates on text that defines a term or concept and then explains its meaning, function, or implications in an expository, reference-style tone. The snippets often introduce a subject and follow with clarifying details, examples, or formal descriptions, as in dictionary, encyclopedia, or how‑it‑works explanations.
rationale: Multiple snippets present a term followed by its explanation or contextual description: the Hebrew word for agency and its usage [0], pronunciation and script variants of a Chinese surname [1], an essay title followed by clarification of Spinoza’s views and their relation to Einstein [2], an article explaining Klan terror with contextual petitions [3], a medical-style explanation of earwax and blockages [4], a news piece describing baboon overpopulation and behavior in a zoo [5], a catalog-style description of an engraving including title and repro ID [6], a short profile explaining a therapy dog’s behavior and role [7], a report on a rare plant’s near-extinction with habitat context [8], a technology explainer on lithium–sulfur batteries and their problem [9], a session description defining medical error and decision-making bias [10], and a home-improvement segment defining exterior walls and their function in the building envelope [11]. The common thread is neutral, explanatory definition or description rather than any moral evaluation, so no Moral Foundations category clearly applies.

short_label: Evidence strength, grading, and quality of studies
long_description: This feature activates on discussions of scientific or clinical evidence that explicitly address its strength, quality, grading, or sufficiency, often in the context of guidelines or treatment recommendations. It highlights mentions of evidence hierarchies, grades (e.g., USPSTF grades), limited or insufficient evidence, and systematic reviews evaluating effectiveness.
rationale: Many snippets explicitly discuss how strong or weak the supporting evidence is, using formal grading systems or hierarchies (e.g., USPSTF grades, ‘gold standard’ RCTs, ‘limited evidence,’ ‘insufficient evidence to rate’), and how that should guide fair, unbiased recommendations or decisions. This is primarily epistemic rather than moral, but to the extent it maps to MFT, it aligns with fairness/cheating via emphasis on rigorous, unbiased evaluation and avoiding overclaiming beyond what evidence justifies. Evidence: USPSTF grades and screening recommendations [0],[1],[3]; explicit discussion of levels of evidence and arguments from authority [2]; lack of high-level evidence in pediatric suctioning [4]; clinical practice guidelines based on higher quality evidence and lower risk of bias [5]; critique of hierarchies of evidence and ‘gold standard’ RCT framing [6]; WHO population-based recommendation based on limited randomized evidence [7]; explicit evidence categories like ‘Unknown effectiveness (limited evidence)’ [9]; formal effectiveness rating scale and ‘Insufficient Evidence to Rate’ [10]; and systematic reviews finding ‘strong evidence’ for acupuncture in specific indications [11].

short_label: Explaining programming syntax and code usage
long_description: This feature activates on instructional text that explains how specific programming constructs, operators, functions, or commands work, often with small code snippets and brief examples. The focus is on clarifying syntax, type behavior, and usage patterns in various languages rather than on broader conceptual theory or morality.
rationale: Many snippets are short how-to explanations of concrete programming details: automatic casting and '+' operator meanings in Java/printing integers as strings [0], MATLAB tasks list and site selection instructions [1], XSLT translate() function syntax and use case [2], Python list comprehension and zip/unpacking to get last elements [3], mixing strings and variables in a GUI text object [4], SQL SELECT with different WHERE conditions for dates and IDs [5], Linux build/install steps with apt-get and tar usage [6], using Integer.parseInt for octal-to-decimal conversion [7], explanation of interface reference memory layout and equality behavior [8], how to comment batch files with REM or :: and their behavior [9], comparison vs logical operators and examples [10], and Q&A-style definitions of server controls, sealed classes, and array vs ArrayList [11]. These are all technical, syntactic explanations without an inherent moral dimension, so no MFT category applies.

short_label: Proper names and formal titles in text
long_description: This feature activates on mentions of proper names and formal titles, especially for organizations, artworks, people, and technical entities (e.g., The Jewish Agency, National Maritime Museum, Ku Klux Klan, Spinoza, Einstein, Baptism of Christ, atool). It seems to track the presence of capitalized multi-word names or labeled entities within explanatory or descriptive prose.
rationale: Many snippets prominently feature capitalized proper nouns and formal titles: institutional names like “The Jewish Agency” [0] and “National Maritime Museum, London” [2]; group names like “Ku Klux Klan” [3]; personal names such as “Spinoza” and “Einstein” [4]; artwork titles like “The Baptism of Christ” [8]; software/tool names like “atool” [9]; and specific medical or biological entities like “Retinal Pigment Epithelial (RPE) Hypertrophy” [10] and “Baker's larkspur” [11]. The commonality is the use of named entities being defined or described, not a moral theme.

short_label: Analyzing causes of problems and failures
long_description: This feature activates on explanatory or technical text that identifies, categorizes, or investigates the causes of problems, failures, incidents, or errors, often in a structured or diagnostic context. It frequently appears with terminology like “cause,” “root cause,” “peril,” “hazard,” and in discussions of troubleshooting, risk assessment, and cause‑and‑effect diagrams.
rationale: Many snippets explicitly focus on determining or organizing the causes of an issue: Ishikawa/fishbone cause‑and‑effect diagrams and root cause analysis in business and design contexts [0,9]; troubleshooting processes that identify and eliminate possible causes of malfunctions [1]; engineering investigation into structural damage and its causes [2]; identification of an unsafe act/condition leading to an accident [3]; analysis of likely causes of an unusual mortality event in sea lions [4]; attribution of a mission failure to a specific process error (measurement system mismatch) [5]; a table explicitly labeled “Problem / Cause of the problem” [6]; definitions of “peril” as a cause of loss and “hazard” as a condition leading to incidents [7]; determining patterns and sources of student errors [8]; listing “main causes” of packaging seal failures [10]; and risk assessment and scenario analysis to identify and evaluate risks and their potential impacts [11]. The common thread is systematic reasoning about what causes undesirable outcomes, not any particular moral stance.

short_label: Definitions and encyclopedic topic introductions
long_description: This feature activates on short encyclopedic-style entries that introduce and define a topic, often beginning with a term and its explanation or contextual overview. The snippets typically provide neutral, factual descriptions of what something is, its background, or its significance.
rationale: Many snippets are clearly definitional or introductory reference-style text: a definition of a pilgrim and pilgrimages with examples across cultures [0]; an explanation of day care/child care including terminology and usage [11]; a concise description of the Amur tiger’s status and population decline framed as an informational report [2]; a historical overview of an iron foundry site and its later use as a high school [3]; a news-style introduction to Bulgaria’s archaeological artifacts and tourism implications [4]; a cultural explanation of Baloch love for homeland with proverb and tradition context [5]; a brief explainer on daylight-saving time with current relevance and public attitudes [6]; a word-of-the-day style explanation of the German verb ‘gelten’ with etymological/semantic context [7]; a mission-description style introduction to the ExoMars landing attempt [8]; a structured summary of an astronomy paper with title, authors, and significance [9]; and a summary of research findings on a gene linked to allergic disorders [10]. These all share the rhetorical function of neutrally introducing and explaining a topic rather than expressing moral judgment, so no specific Moral Foundations category applies.

short_label: Historical and informational expository descriptions
long_description: This feature is activated by neutral, expository prose that provides factual background or historical/contextual description of people, places, institutions, or processes, often in an educational or reference style. The snippets typically summarize origins, roles, or significance (e.g., historical figures, regions, crops, public health topics, or program steps) rather than narrating personal opinions or dialogue.
rationale: Many snippets are concise encyclopedic or textbook-style descriptions: a historical wall in Old San Juan [0], a biblical passage contextualization [1], a child's history of Scotland [2], a brief biographical entry on Eusebius of Laodicea [3], a historical overview of Malaya's late colonial period [5], an explanation of antibiotic use in meat farming [6], an agronomic overview of Zea mays production and uses [8], and a procedural description of community resource mapping in Massachusetts [11]. Even the more narrative or instructional pieces retain an informational, didactic tone [4][7][9][10]. There is no consistent moral valence across care, fairness, loyalty, etc.; the unifying pattern is expository, context-giving description rather than moral evaluation.

short_label: Historical and cultural educational narratives
long_description: This feature activates on expository passages that describe historical events, cultural or religious institutions, and educational contexts, often in a textbook- or article-like style. The snippets typically provide background information, dates, groups, or settings for learning or reflection, rather than personal opinion or dialogue.
rationale: Many snippets are informational descriptions of historical or cultural topics: a Buddhist temple’s history and founding priest [1], Christian persecution and migration to American colonies [7], a forgotten wine region with its multi-ethnic naming history [9], and a presidential nomination narrative with historical figures and epithets [8]. Others are clearly educational contexts or prompts: a youth academy trip framed around Black History Month and civil rights history [2], a teacher-development text about resistance to learning [3], a multicultural children’s book summary about a Korean girl adapting to American school [4], mobile schools for nomadic children [6], Beowulf essay questions [10], and social/cultural influences on Texas [11]. Even the technical snippets [0], [5] are expository explanations of tools or methods. The unifying pattern is didactic, background-giving prose about history, culture, or learning, not a specific moral stance, so no clear Moral Foundations category applies.

short_label: Explanatory / educational informational prose
long_description: This feature activates on neutral, expository writing that explains factual topics—medical issues, historical figures and periods, agriculture, crafts, and children’s activities—often in an instructive or reference style. The common pattern is didactic, third-person prose providing background, definitions, or how‑to guidance rather than narrative or opinionated content.
rationale: Across the snippets, the shared structure is informational explanation: medical/health explanations and warnings ([0], [2], [4], [9]), historical or biographical exposition ([1], [3], [7], [8]), technical or agricultural description ([10]), and step‑by‑step or instructional content ([11]). Even the human‑interest piece about the Burundian mother is written in a reportorial, explanatory tone about socioeconomic conditions ([5]). There is no consistent moral valence around loyalty or other moral foundations; instead, the unifying factor is expository, educational prose conveying facts or instructions.

short_label: Section titles, headings, and labeled fields
long_description: This feature activates on short, often bolded or colon-separated headings and labels that introduce or categorize subsequent content, such as section titles, object types, topic labels, or named entities with descriptors. It appears tied to the structural function of marking and organizing information rather than to any specific subject matter.
rationale: Many snippets begin with or prominently feature heading-like text or labeled fields: e.g., “Yahweh’s Name: The Correct Pronunciation” [0], the table-style labels like “Bioavailability” and “Metabolism” [1], vocabulary entry formatting “outspoken: bold; vocal; vociferous” [2], the article-style title “MicroRNA Regulation of Cardiovascular Functions” [3], “Essay Topic 1” and numbered parts [5], “Object Type: Folder / In root of archive” [6], dictionary/etymology style heading “There’s the Old English dumb, but for DUMB…” [7], bylines and feature titles like “By JANNA SASSER” [8] and “NIH Research Matters / August 13, 2012 / Colon and Rectal Cancers Surprisingly Similar” [10], and labeled common/scientific names and attributes in a wood description table [9]. These all reflect a consistent pattern of structural labels and headings, not moral content, so no MFT category applies.

short_label: Lists of categorical groupings or levels
long_description: This feature activates on text that enumerates items into discrete categories or levels, often using numbered or bulleted lists and short labels (e.g., low/medium/high, size classes, requirements). It reflects a structural pattern of presenting information as grouped facts or tiered classifications rather than any specific topic or moral content.
rationale: Multiple snippets show explicit partitioning of items into ordered or labeled groups: three groupings of regions by prevalence levels [0], three categories of eating speed [8], three groups of oat cultivars by antibody affinity [10], and tiered size labels for diskettes [9]. Others use bullet-point fact lists or requirement levels, such as the Sussex Spaniel facts with size, weight, lifespan, and requirement headings [11], and the muscle fiber type table with distinct fiber categories and attributes [4]. The Eiffel Tower kit description also uses a short bulleted list of included items and constraints [6]. These point to a structural feature for categorical listing and grouping, not a moral foundation.

short_label: Star or numeric rating of quality/value
long_description: This feature activates on explicit evaluative ratings, typically expressed as stars or numeric scores indicating quality, popularity, edibility, or performance of books, videos, plants, websites, essays, or infrastructure. The pattern centers on short rating phrases like “4 of 5 stars,” “Rating: 4.94,” or “quality rating 3-4/4/2-3” that summarize an assessment of something’s value or effectiveness.
rationale: Many snippets contain compact rating expressions that evaluate an item: book star ratings [0][1][3], video rating [2], website rating with votes [4][7], edibility and identification ratings for plants [5][6], essay rating [9], and an infrastructure grade of D+ [10]. The common structure is an explicit, often numeric or star-based, quality or performance assessment, not a moral stance, so no Moral Foundations category clearly applies.

short_label: Section headings, titles, and labeled list items
long_description: This feature activates on structural document elements such as section or chapter titles, labeled headings, and list-style category labels that organize content (e.g., “Title Pages,” “Components of population growth,” “Host City: London, Great Britain”). It reflects textual formatting that introduces or categorizes information rather than narrative content itself.
rationale: Many snippets begin with or consist of headings or labeled fields: a sequence of section titles [0], a list of labeled attributes for plants [1], a software name and version header [2], a study aim sentence that functions as a formal section opener [3], a bolded question-style heading [4], a government section heading followed by explanatory text [5], an assignment description introduced as an event heading [6], structured event metadata like “Host City: London, Great Britain” [7], and definitional or topic-introducing sentences that act as conceptual headings [8][9][10][11]. The commonality is structural/organizational labeling, not moral content, so no MFT category applies.

short_label: Scrabble/anagram word-game descriptions
long_description: This feature activates on text describing Scrabble or similar word games, especially definitions of specific words, their letter compositions, anagrams, hook words, and counts of words that can be formed from given letters. It also fires on closely related word-list and word-formation explanations that enumerate possible derived words and their properties.
rationale: Several snippets explicitly come from Scrabble or word-game contexts, giving dictionary-style definitions, letter breakdowns, and lists of anagrams or shorter words formed from a base word (e.g., filar, Suba, hairnet, KARATS, COMMATA, Tide). These share a consistent pattern: they name a word, state its acceptability in Scrabble/Word with Friends, list its letters, and enumerate anagrams or subwords. This is a topical/structural pattern about word games and anagrammatic word formation, not a moral theme, so no Moral Foundations category applies.

short_label: Reporting and interpreting study findings/results
long_description: This feature activates on scientific or medical writing that explicitly reports, interprets, or summarizes study findings, often using phrases like “these findings suggest,” “our findings indicate,” or “the results of our study show.” It focuses on the rhetorical presentation of empirical results and their implications rather than on any specific topic area.
rationale: Across snippets, the common pattern is formulaic language used to present and interpret research outcomes. Examples include: “These findings show that optimizing the calcination temperature can be used to max–” [1], “The findings from this study suggest…” [2], “The results of our study show that there are significant and similar preventive effects…” [3], “These negative findings… suggest that the gorilla may be the only great ape…” [4], “Our findings indicate that patients with genital warts belong to a high risk group…” [5], “These results suggest farmed specimens are not being substituted for wild plants…” [6], “This study emphasizes that living close to high voltage power lines is a risk…” [7], “The researchers call these findings ‘pretty impressive differences.’ ‘Our findings suggest that…’” [8], “The study's findings will be published… ‘Our data suggests that marriage can have a significant health impact…’” [9], “which support the hypothesized dimensions… Conclusions: The psychometric properties… are adequat–” [10], and “These findings support national and international recommendations…” [11]. Even [0] uses “Collectively, these outcomes demonstrate…” in the same rhetorical role. This is a stylistic/rhetorical feature about reporting empirical results, not a moral one.

short_label: Detection and prevention of harmful misconduct
long_description: This feature activates on content about identifying, detecting, or preventing harmful or illicit behavior or substances, often via technical tools, policies, or educational guidance (e.g., fraud, phishing, abuse, adulteration, dangerous materials). The snippets emphasize recognizing warning signs, securing information or systems, and using formal criteria or instruments to flag risk or wrongdoing.
rationale: Many snippets describe mechanisms to protect people from harm by detecting dangerous or wrongful conditions: identifying allergens in food to prevent reactions [0], detecting adulterated drug-test specimens [1], combating online child sexual abuse [2], securing electronic legal materials against illicit alteration [4], enforcing rules for handling personal and health information [5], warning about scams and fraud schemes [6], educating users about phishing attacks that steal financial data [7], using AI to detect manipulative media bias [8], helping people recognize abusive situations [9], identifying hazardous asbestos in buildings [10], and using a clinical risk score to decide safe treatment settings for pneumonia patients [11]. All of these are framed as protective or preventive measures against physical, emotional, financial, or informational harm, aligning with the Care/harm foundation on the virtue side.

short_label: Mentions of assistants and assistant roles/titles
long_description: This feature activates on references to people holding assistant positions or titles (e.g., assistant professor, assistant administrator, assistant secretary, assistant curator) across varied domains such as academia, government, military, and museums. The pattern is occupational and hierarchical, focusing on the explicit lexical use of “assistant” as part of a role or rank description.
rationale: Many snippets explicitly mention formal hierarchical roles containing the word “assistant,” such as assistant professor, assistant administrator, assistant secretary, assistant commandant, and assistant curator, indicating sensitivity to institutional role structures and subordinate authority positions [0,1,3,4,5,7,10,11]. This is primarily about social hierarchy and organizational structure, which aligns with the Authority/subversion foundation, though the content itself is neutral rather than clearly virtuous or vicious, so the polarity is mixed.

short_label: Section titles and introductory overview text
long_description: This feature activates on structural front-matter and introductory passages that label sections (titles, chapter headings, project names) and briefly describe their purpose or context, often in an expository or academic style. It includes lists of titled parts of a work and opening overview sentences that frame what follows, such as study aims, project descriptions, or assignment prompts.
rationale: Snippet [0] is a pure list of title-page and chapter headings, a strong signal of structural section labels. Snippets [3], [4], [5], [8], [10], and [11] each begin with a heading or topic label followed by a concise overview of a project, study, tutorial, game, or business concept, matching an introductory expository pattern. Snippet [9] similarly contains an assignment-style heading and thesis framing. Even where content is substantive (e.g., [1], [2], [6], [7]), the quoted portions are the opening, framing sentences that introduce a broader discussion, consistent with an introductory/overview function rather than a specific moral theme.

short_label: Section headings and list-style document structure
long_description: This feature activates on texts that present structured document elements such as section or chapter titles, bullet-point or enumerated lists, and labeled fields describing attributes or metadata. The pattern is organizational rather than narrative, emphasizing headings, subheadings, and itemized information across diverse topics.
rationale: Many snippets are dominated by headings and list-like structures: a table of contents with chapter titles [0], a series of labeled bullet points describing plant characteristics [1], and a structured software description with copyright and based-on notes [4]. Others show labeled sections or enumerated metadata such as host city, dates, and participant counts [8], or lesson/unit breakdowns with numbered lessons [11]. Even when topical content varies (religion [3], public health [6], brewing process [10]), the shared feature is the presence of explicit section titles, labels, or list formatting rather than continuous prose. This is an organizational/structural feature, not a moral one.

short_label: Online safety, filtering, and threat detection
long_description: This feature activates for discussions of online safety mechanisms such as content filters, parental controls, anti‑malware/phishing systems, intrusion detection, and tools that protect users’ privacy or block harmful/illegal material. The pattern centers on technical or policy descriptions of detecting, classifying, and restricting dangerous or inappropriate digital content or actors.
rationale: Many snippets describe protecting users—especially children or less-aware users—from harmful or illegal online content, malware, phishing, and privacy threats via filtering or detection systems, which aligns with preventing harm. Examples include parental control and filtering software to block pornography and racism [0][2], tools to protect Facebook users’ privacy from threatening ‘friends’ [3], Google Safe Browsing blocking malware and phishing sites [4], explanations of phishing attacks that steal sensitive information [6], and efforts against online child sexual abuse material [7]. Intrusion detection systems and human-directed cyberattacks are also framed in terms of security and protection [5][9]. These are all about safeguarding people from digital harms, fitting the Care/harm foundation on the virtue side.

short_label: Quantitative rating and scoring of performance
long_description: This feature activates on texts that describe numerical ratings, scores, or indices used to evaluate performance, status, or quality across domains such as countries, health, education, products, or individuals. The pattern emphasizes scales, score ranges, and comparative rankings or thresholds (e.g., 1–7 ratings, 0–10 indices, test scores, quiz cutoffs).
rationale: Many snippets explicitly mention scores, ratings, or indices along with their scales: financial literacy scores and country rankings [0], political rights and civil liberties scores with defined ranges [1][11], health ratings for countries [2], inequality index scores [3], student growth percentiles and test scores [4], a Healthy Eating Quiz score threshold [5], dementia and cognitive test scores and cutoffs [6], banking confidence index percentage [7], and an environmental Green Index score on a 0–10 scale [8]. Even the literary metadata includes a Flesch–Kincaid level, another numeric rating [9][10]. The common thread is quantitative assessment via explicit scoring systems, not a moral foundation per se.

short_label: Announcements of events, observances, and programs
long_description: This feature activates on informational announcements about scheduled events, observance days, courses, workshops, or programs, often including dates, participation details, institutional organizers, and objectives or themes. The text typically has a formal, bulletin-like style describing what the event is, when it occurs, who runs it, and how or why people should take part.
rationale: Many snippets describe specific dated events or observances with logistical details: a 10‑week Greek mythology course with start date and class size limits [0], a short course with application window and enrollment cap [1], National Milk Day with its date and purpose [2], online trauma-informed workshops concluding a project partnership [3], World Information Society Day with its date, origin, and objective [4], National Science Day celebrations with organizing bodies and goals [5], a dated research report on rare earth metals in wastewater [6], accessibility best-practices tied to a DOJ settlement and update date [7], an updated article on fish farming sustainability [8], a teen video competition linked to Sustainable Development Goals and a 2021 initiative [9], Rajasthan State Day with formation history and annual celebration date [10], and a call for proposals with a defined observing period and submission deadline [11]. These all share the pattern of formal announcements or notices about time-bound events or programs rather than a moral theme.

short_label: Section titles, headings, and list-like outlines
long_description: This feature activates on text that consists largely of section titles, headings, or bullet/outline-style lists that organize content (chapters, attributes, metadata, lesson units, etc.). The pattern is structural and typographic rather than topical, marking enumerated or labeled segments that frame or categorize information.
rationale: Many snippets are dominated by headings or list-structured metadata rather than narrative prose. Snippet [0] is a table-of-contents style list of title pages and chapter headings. Snippet [1] is a bullet list of plant attributes. Snippet [3] lists labeled event metadata (Host City, Date Started, Participants, etc.). Snippet [5] is a software header with title, version, and copyright lines. Snippet [7] shows a course/unit heading followed by lesson titles in a list. short_label: Rules limited by higher moral or legal norms
long_description: This feature activates on descriptions of laws, authorities, or rules that are explicitly constrained by superior moral, human-rights, or natural-law principles—i.e., statements that something cannot be commanded, protected, or enforced if it conflicts with dignity, natural law, public order, morality, or higher-ranking rules. It often appears in legal, religious, or policy contexts that define the boundaries of legitimate authority or regulation.
rationale: Several snippets describe authority or legal power as valid only within limits set by higher norms. The Catholic Catechism passage states that no one may command what is contrary to the dignity of persons and natural law, and that authority should express a just hierarchy of values (authority constrained by moral law) [1]. The criminology text on natural law explanations of criminality invokes behaviors that must be universally prohibited because they are morally repugnant or detrimental to normal order [6]. The geographical indications text excludes indications contrary to public order or morality from protection [9]. The Indonesian patent law snippet excludes inventions that are contrary to national laws and regulations from patentability [10]. The New Zealand human rights discussion focuses on laws being inconsistent with the human right to be free from discrimination and the power to declare such inconsistency [11]. Together these show a pattern of discussing when formal authority, law, or protection is invalidated by conflict with higher moral or legal standards, which aligns with the Authority foundation in its virtuous form (legitimate, norm-bounded authority).

short_label: Did-you-know style informational introductions

short_label: Academic critique and critical evaluation writing
long_description: This feature activates for academic or instructional text that discusses critically evaluating, analyzing, or reviewing theories, research, media, or literature, often using terms like “critique,” “critical review,” and “critically analyses.” It centers on the genre and process of scholarly critique, literature reviews, and analytical assessments of works or ideas rather than on their specific content.

This indicates the feature is keyed to the rhetorical function of academic critique and review, not to a specific moral theme.

short_label: Health, immunity, and disease-prevention discourse
long_description: This feature activates on expository or advisory text about human health, focusing on immunity, infection, disease prevention, and biological mechanisms (e.g., immune system strength, infectious disease, microRNA regulation, pharmacokinetics). It often appears in educational or quasi-promotional health contexts that emphasize maintaining or improving bodily well-being and resisting illness.

Together these indicate a pattern around bodily health, purity from disease, and maintaining physical integrity, which aligns with the Sanctity foundation on the virtue side (valuing bodily well-being and protection from contamination/illness).

short_label: Environmental harms, pollution and regulatory criticism
long_description: This feature activates on discussions of environmental damage or public health risks from industrial activity, often framed through criticism of regulators, governments, or international bodies for underestimating, enabling, or mishandling these harms.
